title: 109_s56
content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and the Rio Grande Natural Area Commission. The Act defines key terms such as Commission, Natural Area, and Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF RIO GRANDE NATURAL AREA.

The Rio Grande Natural Area is established in Colorado to conserve natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend a quarter mile on each side of the riverbank. A map and legal description will be prepared by the Secretary for public inspection.

SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF THE COMMISSION. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various organizations and the general public. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, with 4 members representing the general public from the local region. Members serve 5-year terms, can be reappointed, and serve without compensation. The Commission elects a chairperson, meets quarterly, holds public meetings, and provides advance notice of meetings. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission requires advance notice of meetings to be published for the public. The Secretary and other Federal agencies must provide technical assistance requested by the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission requires advance notice of meetings to be published for the public. The Secretary and other Federal agencies must provide technical assistance requested by the Commission. SEC. 5. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission may hold hearings, meetings, and take testimony to carry out the Act. They can enter into cooperative agreements with Colorado, political subdivisions, or individuals for managing non-Federal land. The agreements must notify the Commission of any actions affecting the management plan. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property. The Commission is prohibited from acquiring real property. They shall assist in implementing the management plan to preserve natural, historic, cultural, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. Authorized activities include assisting the State of Colorado in preserving State land and wildlife, increasing public awareness, and encouraging land use policies consistent with the plan. The Commission is tasked with assisting in implementing the management plan for the Natural Area, encouraging political subdivisions and private landowners to adopt land use policies consistent with the plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN.

Not later than 4 years after enactment, the Secretary and Commission, with State agencies, political subdivisions, and private landowners, will prepare management plans for the Natural Area. The Secretary will manage Federal land, and the Commission will manage non-Federal land, submitting plans for approval. The Commission must notify the reasons for disapproval and allow revisions to the management plan. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The management plans must consider existing Federal, State, and local plans for preservation, restoration, and conservation. Plans for Federal land in the Natural Area must comply with relevant laws and be consistent with adjacent land management plans. An inventory of resources in the Natural Area must also be included. The management plans for the Natural Area must include an inventory of resources and recommendations for resource management to protect and preserve the area's natural values. The Secretary is required to publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register. The administration of the natural area is outlined in Section 7. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities and reduction of roads and motorized vehicles. The management plan for the Natural Area includes a reduction in motorized vehicle use and prohibition on Federal land west of the Rio Grande River. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate streamflow changes with Colorado and water users. Private land is subject to the management plan with landowner agreement. Federal land in the area is withdrawn from various activities under public land laws. Land acquisition is also addressed. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation. Any acquired land shall be administered according to the management plan and this Act. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, impose stricter water quality standards, or prevent Colorado from acquiring instream flow rights. 

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funding is authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will end 10 years after the Act's enactment. The Commission established by this Act will terminate 10 years after its enactment.
